<a href="style=%22border-bottom:none!important;%22" target="_blank"></a>
</th>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top:20px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning </strong>and welcome back to the week. Thanks for the thoughtful feedback on yesterday’s unique “What if?” edition of the newsletter. Many of you loved it...others were so angry they addressed us using our middle name. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Either way, it's nice to know there are living, breathing humans on the other side of this email. Don't hesitate to send us a message when you've got strong feelings about things you read in the Brew. We do our best to reply to each one and incorporate your feedback into the news we bring you every morning.</p>
</td>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
REAL ESTATE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/25/states-begin-lifting-eviction-moratoriums?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Rent Day Always Comes too Soon
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Shuttered storefronts" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMTAxL3NodXR0ZXJlZF9zdG9yZWZyb250cy5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Mario Tama/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In the next week, millions of households and businesses will face their third rent payment during the pandemic. But this one might be the most worrying yet as state bans on evictions <a href="https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/05/23/860857378/with-moratorium-lifted-houston-becomes-largest-u-s-city-where-evictions-can-resu?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">start to lift</a>.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Residential</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">After being halted for two months because of the coronavirus, evictions can resume in Texas. And while some cities have added extra protections for renters, a “tsunami of evictions” is still expected, NPR reports. A rental assistance program in Houston ran out of funding in 1.5 hours.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Wisconsin’s evictions ban also </span><span><a href="https://www.sfchronicle.com/business/article/California-advances-bill-allowing-some-15289521.php?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">expires</a></span><span> today. The state is setting up a $25 million rent assistance program...but it’s not expected to be accessible until early June. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Evictions and damaged credit can turn into a vicious cycle of housing insecurity even during a strong economy. Tack on skyrocketing unemployment and a pent up wave of evictions could hammer working families further. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Commercial </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Like humans, businesses have also withheld rent during the pandemic, especially in hard-hit sectors like retail and hospitality.  </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Chipotle, Dunkin', and Shake Shack are among the chains </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/landlords-fume-as-starbucks-other-chains-seek-extended-rent-cuts-11589889601?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">lobbying</a></span><span> property owners to defer rent payments or renegotiate leases. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Starbucks </span><span><a href="https://www.foxbusiness.com/money/starbucks-landlords-astounded-coronavirus-rent-reduction?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">told</a></span><span> landlords it’ll “require concessions” for at least a 12-month period starting in June.  </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But many landlords are peeved that blue-chip companies worth billions⁠—who can raise money through a variety of sources⁠—are seeking concessions at their expense. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>Even in states where commercial evictions can technically proceed, closed and bottlenecked courts mean they’re unlikely to happen soon.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Landlords</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Faced with empty storefronts, many landlords are being flexible with their tenants. Some are working on arrangements to extend leases in exchange for forgiven rent. Reduced rent agreements could hurt them in the long run by diminishing property values, per the WSJ. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Landlords also have mortgages, utility bills, and property taxes, and as their income dries up, failure to pay could have city-wide consequences. Commercial landlord Vornado Realty Trust said about 80% of NYC retail tenants <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/21/nyregion/commercial-rent-NYC-coronavirus.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">missed payments</a> at the beginning of April and May⁠. If building owners can’t scrounge up money for their next property tax bill in July, NYC will lose out on crucial revenue that funds public services. </p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GEOPOLITICS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/25/us-china-ramp-war-words-many-issues?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
U.S. and China Pick Up Where They Left Off
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If there’s one thing you can count on even during a pandemic, it’s Phil Mickelson-level trash talk between the U.S. and China. The world’s two biggest economies <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-05-25/u-s-blacklisting-33-china-entities-risks-potential-retaliation?srnd=premium&sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">ramped up</a> their hostilities this weekend across really every issue you can imagine, from trade to telecommunications. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The Chinese Foreign Minister said aggressive U.S. politicians are </span><span><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-05-24/beijing-urges-u-s-to-drop-wishful-thinking-of-changing-china?sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pushing</a></span><span> the nations into a “new Cold War.”</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Why the U.S. is angry with China: </strong>The Trump administration has faulted China for allowing the coronavirus to spread beyond the origin city of Wuhan. It’s also criticized a proposed law that would expand controls over Hong Kong. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Why China is angry with the U.S.: </strong>The U.S. recently tightened restrictions on supplies to Huawei (one of China’s most important tech companies), citing national security concerns. It also added 33 more Chinese entities to a <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-china-blacklist/dozens-of-chinese-companies-added-to-u-s-blacklist-in-latest-beijing-rebuke-idUSKBN22Y2QR?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">trade blacklist</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>When President Trump launched a trade war with China a few years ago, most experts suggested it was less about specific tariffs and more about larger geopolitical battles. We’re starting to see those in action. </p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
INVESTING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/25/new-york-stock-exchange-back?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Stonk Exchange Is Back
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="NYSE" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC85MzEvc3RvY2tfZXhjaGFuZ2UuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Wallpaper Flare</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Today, the New York Stock Exchange will reopen its iconic trading floor, giving bored traders a break from hawking Silly Bandz to their neighbors. The NYSE will cap the number of traders on the floor at a quarter of normal capacity, and those who do return will be asked to sign a liability waiver.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory: </strong>The world’s largest stock exchange barred brokers from the trading floor in late March as the dangers of the coronavirus materialized. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The comeback story: </strong>In an opinion column for the WSJ, NYSE President Stacey Cunningham <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-nyse-will-reopen-the-trading-floor-11589487300?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">wrote</a>, “Two months later, we’ve learned a lot.” </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>New </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/nyses-floor-to-reopen-with-masks-coronavirus-waivers-and-handshake-ban-11590404400?mod=hp_lead_pos9&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">safety measures</a></span><span> will require traders to wear masks and avoid public transportation, while plexiglass barriers have been erected to promote social distancing. That means no bear (or bull) hugs if the Dow hits 30k. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>While electronic trading has reduced the significance of the physical NYSE to financial markets, its reopening is a symbol of Wall Street’s gradual return to business as usual.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://www.brightcellars.com/?n_id=mbrew&a_id=mb052620b&d=2&sixbtl=bc" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Bright Cellars</a> are a bunch of nerds—this is a business newsletter; we love nerds; look at these semicolons—and they figured out how to scientifically determine what wine you like and deliver that wine <a href="https://www.brightcellars.com/?n_id=mbrew&a_id=mb052620b&d=2&sixbtl=bc" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">to your door</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Bright Cellars was founded by two MIT grads who developed an algorithm that chooses wines for you, and they know what you’ll be into based on your answers to their <a href="https://www.brightcellars.com/?n_id=mbrew&a_id=mb052620b&d=2&sixbtl=bc" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">wine quiz</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">They’ve assured us the quiz isn’t as hard as getting into MIT. Unless “what kind of chocolate do you like” was on your SAT, in which case, we have further questions for you.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A Bright Cellars <a href="https://www.brightcellars.com/?n_id=mbrew&a_id=mb052620b&d=2&sixbtl=bc" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">membership</a> is more than just a wine delivery service; it’s a full-on wine education. Their algorithm is a personalized experience that helps you learn about wines and expand your palette.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">No need to leave the house for some relaxing wine. <a href="https://www.brightcellars.com/?n_id=mbrew&a_id=mb052620b&d=2&sixbtl=bc" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Get 50% off your first box of six bottles on us</a>.</p>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">

</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/25/virgin-orbit-successfully-launches-experimental-rocket-space?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
If You're Not Launching Rockets...
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<img alt="Virgin Orbit" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMTAyL3Zpcmdpbl9vcmJpdC5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Virgin Orbit</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em>Editor's Note: The headline of this story was updated to reflect that the launch was unsuccessful. </em></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Are you even a polarizing, outspoken billionaire? Virgin Group founder Richard Branson watched on as his team tried to carry out the launch of the new Virgin Orbit spacecraft yesterday. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">It didn't go as planned</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The LauncherOne rocket dropped out from the bottom of a specially outfitted Boeing 747 jet...but moments later controllers had to <a href="https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-52802520?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">abort</a> the mission following an "anomaly." </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The ultimate goal for Virgin Orbit is to help </span><span><a href="https://www.theverge.com/2020/5/25/21265057/virgin-orbit-launcherone-rocket-test-launch-747-airplane-cosmic-girl?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">deploy commercial and government satellites</a></span><span> into orbit by offering more flexible launch locations, aka...anywhere. “We can fly to space from any place that can host a 747,” explained CEO Dan Hart. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Obviously, that plan has a few more wrinkles to be ironed out. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">But don’t forget about Elon:</strong> Tomorrow, SpaceX looks to redeem the week for rocketry with its first-ever crewed mission. When the <a href="https://www.sciencealert.com/spacex-is-about-to-launch-two-astronauts-into-space-in-a-world-first?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">two NASA astronauts</a> take off from Florida, it will be the first manned launch from U.S. soil into Earth's orbit in nine years.</p>

width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMTAxL3NodXR0ZXJlZF9zdG9yZWZyb250cy5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eMario Tama/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn the next week, millions of households and businesses will face their third rent payment during the pandemic. But this one might be the most worrying yet as state bans on evictions \u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/05/23/860857378/with-moratorium-lifted-houston-becomes-largest-u-s-city-where-evictions-can-resu?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003estart to lift\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eResidential\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAfter being halted for two months because of the coronavirus, evictions can resume in Texas. And while some cities have added extra protections for renters, a “tsunami of evictions” is still expected, NPR reports. A rental assistance program in Houston ran out of funding in 1.5 hours.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eWisconsin’s evictions ban also \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.sfchronicle.com/business/article/California-advances-bill-allowing-some-15289521.php?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eexpires\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e today. The state is setting up a $25 million rent assistance program...but it’s not expected to be accessible until early June. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eEvictions and damaged credit can turn into a vicious cycle of housing insecurity even during a strong economy. Tack on skyrocketing unemployment and a pent up wave of evictions could hammer working families further. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eCommercial \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLike humans, businesses have also withheld rent during the pandemic, especially in hard-hit sectors like retail and hospitality.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eChipotle, Dunkin', and Shake Shack are among the chains \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/landlords-fume-as-starbucks-other-chains-seek-extended-rent-cuts-11589889601?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elobbying\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e property owners to defer rent payments or renegotiate leases. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eStarbucks \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.foxbusiness.com/money/starbucks-landlords-astounded-coronavirus-rent-reduction?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etold\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e landlords it’ll “require concessions” for at least a 12-month period starting in June.  \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut many landlords are peeved that blue-chip companies worth billions⁠—who can raise money through a variety of sources⁠—are seeking concessions at their expense. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eEven in states where commercial evictions can technically proceed, closed and bottlenecked courts mean they’re unlikely to happen soon.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eLandlords\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFaced with empty storefronts, many landlords are being flexible with their tenants. Some are working on arrangements to extend leases in exchange for forgiven rent. Reduced rent agreements could hurt them in the long run by diminishing property values, per the WSJ. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLandlords also have mortgages, utility bills, and property taxes, and as their income dries up, failure to pay could have city-wide consequences. Commercial landlord Vornado Realty Trust said about 80% of NYC retail tenants \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/21/nyregion/commercial-rent-NYC-coronavirus.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emissed payments\u003c/a\u003e at the beginning of April and May⁠. If building owners can’t scrounge up money for their next property tax bill in July, NYC will lose out on crucial revenue that funds public services. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS Off\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf there’s one thing you can count on even during a pandemic, it’s Phil Mickelson-level trash talk between the U.S. and China. The world’s two biggest economies \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-05-25/u-s-blacklisting-33-china-entities-risks-potential-retaliation?srnd=premium\u0026sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eramped up\u003c/a\u003e their hostilities this weekend across really every issue you can imagine, from trade to telecommunications. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe Chinese Foreign Minister said aggressive U.S. politicians are \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-05-24/beijing-urges-u-s-to-drop-wishful-thinking-of-changing-china?sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epushing\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e the nations into a “new Cold War.”\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhy the U.S. is angry with China: \u003c/strong\u003eThe Trump administration has faulted China for allowing the coronavirus to spread beyond the origin city of Wuhan. It’s also criticized a proposed law that would expand controls over Hong Kong. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhy China is angry with the U.S.: \u003c/strong\u003eThe U.S. recently tightened restrictions on supplies to Huawei (one of China’s most important tech companies), citing national security concerns. It also added 33 more Chinese entities to a \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-china-blacklist/dozens-of-chinese-companies-added-to-u-s-blacklist-in-latest-beijing-rebuke-idUSKBN22Y2QR?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etrade blacklist\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eWhen President Trump launched a trade war with China a few years ago, most experts suggested it was less about specific tariffs and more about larger geopolitical battles. We’re starting to see those in action. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-top: 12px;\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F05%2F25%2Fus-china-ramp-war-words-many-issues\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"\" style=\"display: inline-block; The NYSE will cap the number of traders on the floor at a quarter of normal capacity, and those who do return will be asked to sign a liability waiver.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory: \u003c/strong\u003eThe world’s largest stock exchange barred brokers from the trading floor in late March as the dangers of the coronavirus materialized. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe comeback story: \u003c/strong\u003eIn an opinion column for the WSJ, NYSE President Stacey Cunningham \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-nyse-will-reopen-the-trading-floor-11589487300?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewrote\u003c/a\u003e, “Two months later, we’ve learned a lot.” \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eNew \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/nyses-floor-to-reopen-with-masks-coronavirus-waivers-and-handshake-ban-11590404400?mod=hp_lead_pos9\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esafety measures\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e will require traders to wear masks and avoid public transportation, while plexiglass barriers have been erected to promote social distancing. That means no bear (or bull) hugs if the Dow hits 30k. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong
